People are always asking me: "Where is that Waterfall that falls on the beach?"
The answer is: Julia Pfeiffer Burns State Park.
Yo can't get there right now, the park is closed.
Aside from that, it's on the south side of the Pfeiffer Canyon Bridge. They are rebuilding the bridge, it will be completed in late September or early October.
So access is denied from the north.
As of this writing - July 2017 - there are still mud and rock slides to the south of there. So access is denied from the south.
Mud and rock slides??
It's not raining, hasn't rained in months.
Let me explain.
The late winter rains were so intense, that the slides were so bad, they are still trying to get them cleared.
At the extreme south end, 50 miles south of the being rebuilt bridge, is a rock slide so large, it's the biggest, in the over 40 years I have lived on the coast. That slide alone added 16 acres of new coastline to Big Sur.
Because the ocean all along Big Sur is a National Marine Sanctuary, the can't push any material over the edge.
It all has to scooped up and put into dump trucks, and hauled away. For the largest rock slide in recent history, that's a tall order, not to mention an enormous expense.
There are estimating it will take a year to get the highway open on the south end.
So plan on visiting the park, after it opens, after the bridge is rebuilt. Late September or early October.

A Short Walk Lead You to See the Amazing McWay Falls

Julia Pfeiffer Burns State Park (朱莉婭．菲佛．伯恩斯州立公園) is located between Big Sur and Mud Creek near mile marker 35.8 on the beautiful CA-1 coast highway (Highway 1). The 1,522 Hectare (3,762 acres) park was named after Julia Pfeiffer Burns (1868-1928), a local and legendary early pioneer woman and resident of Big Sur. The McWay Falls, McWay Creek and McWay Canyon are named after Christopher McWay, an early settler and farmer from New York State who arrived in the area with his son Christopher Jr. around 1874. The park extends from the Big Sur coastline to the nearby 915 m (3,000 ft) ridge.

We drove from the south to this amazing California state park. We were lucky to find free roadside parking along the west side of Highway 1. We went across the street and followed the sign to the official parking lot which led us to a tunnel under the highway. After the short tunnel, we turned right and followed the trail to the McWay Waterfall House. The 107 m (352 ft) long trail is right on the edge of the cliff and offers a magnificent view of the McWay Canyon, McWay Cove, McWay Beach and the McWay Falls. Most of the visitors like us brought out cameras and took photos. We could see the beach and the cove below, surrounded by ridges. Before 1983, the beach was non-existent and the falls fell directly to the ocean below. The 1983 huge rainfall resulted in several landslides and mudflows. The mudflow entered the ocean immediately to the north of the falls, creating the beach we see today. In few minutes, we saw the famous McWay Falls right in front of us. The 24 m (80 ft) waterfall seemed small from where we stood because the trail is higher up than the top of the falls. The water flow was not huge and significant, but it is one of two waterfalls in California that cascade directly into the ocean, the other being Alamere Falls. At the end of trail, we saw the Waterfall House that was the house of Lathrop and Helene Brown. Later in 1961, Helene Hooper Brown donated the entire property to the state. The mansion was demolished in 1966.

It is sad to learn that Julia Pfeiffer Burns State Park is closed and not accessible from both sides of Highway 1 due to road closures, rock slides and dangerous conditions. It is hard to say when it will reopen again. You can check the latest information about the park from park website.

The Julia Pfeiffer Burns State Park is absolutely worth your time... if you're interested in visiting a relaxing and naturally beautiful location. There is an added bonus... often, the park is empty... and you can enjoy the views without having to feel pressured to move along so others can enjoy the view.

As soon as you turn into the park you will find two different parking areas. The smaller of the two areas is near where you pay (honor system) and also near the toilets.

If you walk inland from the parking area there is an easy to follow path that follows a small creek. The path has very gentle elevation rises through old-growth Redwood trees. After about 20-25 minutes you'll come to small three-tier waterfall. There is a bench at the base of the waterfall where you can sit and enjoy the serene beauty.

If you walk toward the ocean from the parking lot you will take an easy path that takes you through a short walking tunnel that allows you to pass under the highway. This path then takes you to the end of the continent. There is a beautiful cove with a pencil thin waterfall that makes the trip worth while -- this is a good investment of your time.

We stopped at Julia Pfeiffer Burns State park to check out McWay Falls and hike the Ewoldsen trail.

McWay Falls is beautiful, and there a short walk (not strenuous at all) to see a very different looking points.

We then hiked the Ewoldsen trail and we are so happy we did! The trail is 6.2 miles and can be strenuous at times. In the beginning of the hike, you are hiking through a redwood forrest with beautiful trees and creeks. As you move higher up, you begin to see views of the ocean. At the summit, there are the most incredible views as you high up in the mountains but still have the view of the ocean. We were so happy we did it. It is definitely strenuous and I believe it took us around 3-4 hours in total. We did stop a lot of take pictures, but I would budget around that much time.

Many travel sites we looked at suggesting doing both McWay and Ewoldsen hike in the same day if you only have one day in Big Sur, which is what we ended up doing. I would highly recommend it.

We hiked the Edwoldsen trail and loop and loved it. The canyon views are beautiful and the open beauty of the ocean vistas are incredible. The trail to the loop is just over a mile with a set of switch backs and passing through groves of old growth redwoods. It took us approximately 40 minutes hiking to the start of the loop as we took in the beauty and shot photographs. We opted for the right turn at the start of the approximate two mile loop and passed through beautiful canyons and redwoods before breaking out into views of the ocean and canyons before the turn off to the Vista trail to the top. You realize the incredible beauty of Big Sur on this 4.5 mile hike. We ate lunch at the top of the vista with views up and down the pacific coastline. We spent some time at the top just taking it all in. The second half of the loop to the return of the trail back to the parking lot is filled with canyon views, ocean views and redwood groves.

There is approximately 1,600 feet of vertical for this hike, however it is very doable in good walking shoes. Footing is not an issue however you would want to keep small children close as there are some sections with very steep drop-offs by the side of the trail. We saw a 3 or 4 groups of parents with children under 10 enjoying themselves.

We parked on Hwy 1 as the parking was full with more than 90% of the visitors doing the waterfall hike. Visit Both Sides of this Wonderful Park!

You absolutely must see the waterfall and the coastline, but don't skip the trail along the creek on the other side of Hwy 1. Walk beneath those wonderful huge redwood trees and enjoy the sunlight filtered through the treetops. Take the longer trail of the ridge (Eswolden) or stay in the canyon; both are superb. Take the short trail down to the building that houses the Pelton Wheel and learn a snippet of history. Go to youtube and listen to Johnny Rivers' great song "Going Back To Big Sur." If the parking lot is full, park on the side of Hwy 1 where the shoulder is wide, and avoid paying the fee.

We drove the spectacular coast highway from Carmel to the state park, about 37 miles of breathtaking curving roadway along the mountains at the ocean, to go see the McKey waterfall trail. As spectacular as the rest of the scenery was on the highway, it still does not prepare you for the site at the end of short, easy trail from the parking area. (The parking lot was full, but you can wait at the gate for a few minutes and a space will open up, as many visitors spend less than 30 minutes in the park).The trail passes under the highway and travels up the south side of small, rocky sided cove, out towards the sea, from there you can look back and see the McKey waterfall pouring onto a small beach, and then into the ocean. The colors are incredible. We were lucky to visit on a sunny day and the water in the cove was an a teal green, cobalt blue combination that was unforgettable. But we took pictures anyway. This was definitely worth the drive. As a bonus, you get to drive over and see the famous Bixby Bridge

Awesome, must see stop along Highway 1

This is a great State park. A very short walk takes you from the parking lot west to the overlook for McWay falls. THis waterfall is gorgeous as it flows into the little bay full of aqua coloered water. This is maybe the most popular spot on Highway 1 so it does get crowded during heavy use periods (like Memorial day weekend when we were there). Heading east from the parking lot is aloso great. THere is an easy trial up to a nice waterfall and I highly recommend continuing along the Ewoldsen trail where you get to see a lot more of the small stream, big redwood trees, Oak trees, and overlooks of the ocean. THere are some steep areas of the trail and a walking stick might help. Bring plenty of water as you will work up a sweat. Also be on the lookout for ticks. They are around. Wearing light colored clothing helps to see them better but do a thorough check when you get back to the car. Worth that little inconvenience however. We got there early, like 7:30 AM early and were able to get a spot in the parking lot. Not too much after that the lot was full and they only let a car in if another car leaves. There is parking along highway 1 but be careful if you do that.
